Posts.Content: May 27, 2008 10:27PM nosurrender wrote: I am an avid gardener and  I refuse to let cancer take away my favorite thing in the world.... so I found opera length rose gloves! They are at garden shops, and are made for working with roses. They go past the elbow so you are fairly protected. Here is one pair I found online- there are MANY to choose from: http://www.bionicgloves.com/shop/?id=38&cat=28 I have an Emergency LE station in my guest bath. I have Betadine cleanser, then I put on regular Betadine followed by Bacitracin and then I dress the wound as needed- be it a bandaid or 4x4 gauze.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2007 03:16PM - edited Oct 6, 2007 03:16PM by nosurrender Poppy, I am so glad people are acting quickly to help you. Please know that they have to tell you all the what-ifs. But sometimes docs forget to tell us the but-it-probably-is-just-this! Now your biopsy was taken and you have absolutely nothing more to do about it except wait. Worrying will not change the results- worrying will only make you feel worse. So try to do this- and I know it is hard- tell yourself that you have nothing to worry about because you don't know anything - which is true! When and IF you should get bad news, THEN you are allowed to worry. But give yourself a break and breathe. Take the phone out of the fridge. Give yourself the weekend off. You can get all ramped up again on Monday - but this weekend? You are on holiday from worry. OK? Please let us know how you do!! Love, g

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 01:16PM nosurrender wrote: This was a  really good article on constipation that was in CURE magazine. Apparently there is a new drug out there that really helps if you are on pain killers: IN EVERY ISSUE:CURE 2008 Keep It Moving BY LACEY MEYER Constipation during treatment can be alleviated. Suffering from constipation is no longer an accepted part of cancer treatment. Whether it’s a side effect of chemotherapy or opioids (narcotic medications) used to treat cancer-related pain, today there are many ways to alleviate constipation without interfering with cancer treatment or pain relief.  CAUSES > Constipation results when stools stay in the bowel too long, becoming dry and difficult to pass. Some classes of chemotherapy drugs, such as vinca alkaloids, taxanes, and platinum agents, affect the nerve supply to the bowel and slow down the natural movement and rhythm of the intestines in addition to affecting appetite and normal physical activity abilities. Up to 90 percent of cancer patients experience cancer-related pain, and opioids, such as morphine, hydrocodone (Vicodin, Lortab) and oxycodone (Percocet, OxyContin), frequently cause constipation. Opioids effectively relieve pain by binding to certain receptors in the brain and spinal cord, but they also bind to receptors found in the intestines, leading to constipation in about half of patients by disrupting contractions that help move stools downward. Without contractions, stools stay in the intestines longer and become dry and hard as the body reabsorbs the water. MANAGEMENT > Constipation is one of the most common and debilitating side effects in patients taking opioids, and since constipation can be predicted, a bowel regimen should always begin at the same time as opioid use. Several over-the-counter medications are available, including stimulant laxatives Senokot (senna) and Dulcolax (bisacodyl), which increase contractions in the bowel; stool softeners, such as Colace and Surfak (docusate), which help retain water in the bowel to soften the stool; and osmotic laxatives, such as lactulose, which use osmosis to pull water into the intestines. To achieve optimum results, a stimulant is typically given with a stool softener to move the stool through the intestines before the body reabsorbs the water. Studies show it is unlikely that stimulant laxative use at the recommended dose will cause dependency. In addition, there is no risk of so-called rebound constipation after stopping laxative intake, according to research published in The American Journal of Gastroenterology. In April, the Food and Drug Administration approved Relistor (methylnaltrexone) to treat opioid-induced constipation in patients with late-stage, advanced illnesses, including cancer, AIDS, and lung disease. Relistor, which is given by subcutaneous injection (under the skin), blocks the opioid receptor in the gastrointestinal tract but because it cannot cross the blood-brain barrier it does not interfere with opioids’ pain-relieving properties housed in the brain. Relistor is the first drug approved for opioid-induced constipation, and studies for this indication are under way with similar agents, including Entereg (alvimopan), oral PEG-Naloxol, and Naloxone. PREVENTION > In addition to doctor-recommended medications, prevention strategies should be utilized as much as possible to promote regular bowel movement and function. Eating high-fiber foods such as beans, peaches, squash, broccoli, carrots, and whole-grain bread and bran can minimize constipation because fiber helps to hold water in the stool, making it heavier and able to move through the intestines faster. Experts recommend 20 to 35 grams of fiber per day, but this should be accompanied by sufficient amounts of non-caffeinated fluid because fiber without enough fluids can result in hard, dry stools. Some fiber preparations cause gas, so patients can experiment with different fiber products or use antigas medications such as simethicone. The recommended 30 minutes of moderate exercise each day not only helps to stay in shape, but also serves as a preventive measure for cancer patients at an increased risk of constipation. Physical activity helps move food through the bowels, while lack of activity can slow food by reducing muscle contractions in the intestines and abdomen.
Posts.Title: PET/CT shows bone and liver mets marshakb nancyc

Posts.Content: Jan 16, 2009 05:28PM nosurrender wrote: Marsha, it looks like that Relistor is something you have to get from the doctor. I am sorry I didn't see your post earlier so you could have given them a call.  I bet the fact that you can't be physically active is making this worse. Does bearing down hurt your back too? That can make it painful to go and then that helps make the constipation worse...It is like a vicious cycle! I hope you don't get an impaction. If worst comes to worst there is always Fleets Phospho Soda that they sell in the little green bottles at the drug store. It comes in "lemon" flavor - but drink a chaser of a soda you like to kill the taste of it. That stuff is like dynamite. It is what they give to start the clean out process for a colonoscopy.   The duclolax and stool softeners work well too, but they can take a couple of days. The Phospho soda is faster. Also, if it has been a long time since you went, you may have hard stools. My onc told me to use a mineral oil Fleets to soften followed by a regular Fleets- but I don't know if you can be doing the contorting required to get a Fleets- you have to lie on the floor on your left side or with your butt in the air and that would be really hard for you I think right now... Try the prune juice but have some phospho soda in the house just in case. I really hope you go soon. Hang in there, Marsha!

Posts.Content: May 5, 2008 03:55PM nosurrender wrote: Hi Apple, There was a study done by ASCO a couple of years back that found that 70% of all BC is cured by surgery alone. I was diagnosed in 2001 and had surgery and did six months of chemo and then rads. My sister was diagnosed 2 years later and only did surgery and rads. We are both still here. My sister has a horse farm and she never missed a day of what she needed to do  there. My personal opinion is hit it hard when you are first diagnosed. That is the best way to knock down your tumor and  ensure a long, cancer free life. Chemo and rads sound really scary, but they don't last forever and you can keep up with your life while doing them.  The thing thing about cancer is you can't hide from it. It follows you. And next year, wouldn't you rather know that you did EVERYTHING you could to beat it rather than, I wish I had done something about this.... It is all a personal decision, and the fear can really make decisions so much harder to make. But I have had cancer twice, two totally unrelated to each other, I have done chemo twice, and I am fine now and living life to the fullest. You can do this. You will need to have a big family meeting and delegate some of the household chores that normally will fall on you... but you have nine kids! I am sure they would be happy to help out when you are not feeling up to snuff. Good luck with whatever you decide. Hugs, g

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2007 10:31AM nosurrender wrote: My first time around with cancer my onc had me go for a round of tests so I could have a baseline to compare future scans to. I think they are a good idea because I did find another cancer later on. Kim, after rads my lungs lit up. It took a while for them to get back to normal. I now have a couple of lung nodules that are being watched. Lung nodules are normal in everyone, but once you get bc dx they go into vigilant mode and watch even normal things carefully. This is where my baseline scans have served me well. They know nothing is "new" so there is no need to go to extremes.

Posts.Content: nosurrender wrote: Hey LE-ers I have bi-lat LE. It is worse on the left side where I had my original cancer in 2001. Last week I was putting leaves in a garbage bag. Not a lot of leaves. No heavy raking, they were already in a pile. I was wearing long pants, socks, sneakers, I had both arms wrapped with leather gardening gloves on. Afterwards, I did not have any cuts or scratches. I did an le massage when I was taking my shower when I came inside when I was done. Fast forward to 2 days later... I have a raging fever, incredible pain and wound up in the hospital with cellulitis. I am still sick. I may lose my tissue expander. How the hell did this happen????  nosurrenderbreastcancerhelp.org ~What a long, strange trip it's been... Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: I did everything right...??? nosurrender rrs

Posts.Content: May 10, 2008 08:16AM nosurrender wrote: My doc had me wait about three weeks. Your blood counts can actually be lowered from rads, so they want you to heal  and rebuild your resources. There are a lot of Pre-Rad stuff that has to be done during that time off. You have to get mapped, which is them figuring out exactly where the radiation beams will go. This takes a couple of visits to the rad center. You will also get tatoos. They are just tiny blue dots that look like ballpoint pen marks, they use them to line up the measurements the mapping figured out. Once you start, though, the actual rad appointment takes about 5 minutes! Good luck! g
Posts.Title: how soon to start rads after chemo collector collector

Posts.Content: May 5, 2008 07:43AM nosurrender wrote: Hi everyone, I just wanted to report I am MUCH better. The skin is a human color and the redness and pain has really improved. I have a lot of fluid collected under the expander but that will be taken care of next week when I get my exchange done. Tender and Sahalie, that is something that is so frustrating - a microscopic scratch or in your husband's case Sahalie, a scratch from his nurse? I do use purell religiously. I keep a big bottle in my car. and I bleached down the whole house this weekend. I will take your advice Sue and Grace and fight for my sleeves! BTW-yes they did put the iv in my other arm in the er. Even after I gave them the whole speech. The new one they are countering with is that if they don't add fluids to the drip, then the risk is reduced.  I know. there I am for an infection on the other side and they say fluids from a saline drip will cause LE. Thanks again for all your help! love, g

Posts.Title: doing okay 3boys4me MNDOT

Posts.Content: May 3, 2008 08:51AM nosurrender wrote: Hi everyone, I woke up this morning and the pain is finally subsiding a bit. I also have a more natural, human color to my skin. I never heard of spontaneaous infection. My PS said that because my skin is radiated and I have a foreign object in there I am more prone to things like this happening. It came on suddenly. I woke up feeling like my skin was inside out and all my nerve endings were exposed. Then it started to concentrate in the axilla and around the tissue expander. It was then that I called my PS and asked him if I should go ahead and take one of the Levaquin I have in the house. I did and then a few hours later my temp spiked and I felt about as bad as I ever felt. The next morning I went to the ER and they gave me IV antibiotics and I got myself released because we had a big family wedding that day. I missed the ceremony but made it to the reception. I really don't want to miss any joyful events so it was important to me. My wbc has gone down finally. So this is just the residual infection working its way out. But I have to say, this hurt more than my surgery did. I have been very unhappy with my LE place. In fact, just last week, before this happened, I complained to them because my arms have not gone down one bit since I started last summer. I asked for sleeves and they said their sleeve provider doesn't accept my insurance and I would have to "let my fingers do the walking" in the phone book and find my own place. The other LE place I went to before my cancer returned had a custom made sleeve made for me with no trouble at all. I don't even know what to order. This whole thing has been such a shock to me. I know when I have been bad and not as careful as I should be. But I have been extraordinarily careful and especially last week because I wanted my arms to be as small as possible for the wedding. Thanks for all your support and for educating me on this. I had no idea. Love, g
Posts.Title: I did everything right...??? nosurrender rrs

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2007 01:40PM nosurrender wrote: Diana, Everyone who has responded is so right. Your doctor works FOR YOU. Not the other way around. You went to him because HE is the one who went to medical school so HE can tell you what he thinks is best- not pass the buck onto someone else. By saying your margins are "close" seems to me like he is covering his butt. I always thought that a clear 1cm margin  was a good distance. Is he saying he wants to re-excise the area to get cleaner margins? Is he suggesting that radiation will take care of this? Before you do anything I would see another breast surgeon and bring your films. I would also ask to have your tissue samples sent to a large hospital for a second opinion. My original tumor was sent to Memorial Slone Kettering for another opinion. Thankfully, their pathologist agreed with the original pathologist. I would also speak to an oncologist as well. It is better to get a re-excision in my opinion and be sure you have all the cancer removed then to be "hoping" that the radiation will take care of it. I would think twice about using that doc again though. I know it seems like a lot of work and hassle now- but in the long run, you will be happy you got everything taken care of NOW rather than later. Good luck with everything! g my site
Posts.Title: HELP!.......pathology results from lumpectomy momtoangels hopefor30

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2009 01:40PM nosurrender wrote: So many new diagnoses! Hi girls, I just thought you might feel a little reasurred to hear from an old timer... I know when I was first diagnosed all I wanted was to hear from someone who had been through everything already. I was first diagnosed at age 39 in 2001. I am still here! When you are first diagnosed it is the worst time. Everything is being thrown at you- all these new terms and you almost have to get a medical degree in a week to understand.  You will feel much better when you have a plan in place and you have made the best decisions for yourself. The best thing to do right now is to not think too far ahead. Don't project to next month or next year. Just do what you have to do now. Just worry about what you have to worry about right at this very moment... nothing more. It will all work out in time.  It is OK to be scared. It is also OK to give yourself permission to think of yourself as someone who will beat this and have it all behind them.  There are over 2 million survivors walking around doing just fine in the US right now with all of this behind them. There are incredible advances that have been made and your future may be a bit nerve wracking right now- but- once you arm yourself with all the info you need, get your plan in place, and do what you have to do, you will get back to your life again.  I promise! Hang in there!! Hugs, g

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2007 06:09PM nosurrender wrote: Hi Joanne, The sources are all cited. All you have to do is click on the  parenthetical links - for example, [12], and it will direct you to the exact study that is being quoted. The researcher has attended practically all of these oncology conferences and has extensively studied the latest test and trial results and put them all together for me to share with you. As you can read at the bottom, the studies you see here will be presented at December's San Antonio Breast Cancer symposium. This man was even kind enough to present a dear friend of mine's case to a group of top oncologists at one of their round table discussions. She has mets and is not responding well to tx and is also triple neg. She gave her onc his findings and he knew all the doctors and was considering the recommendations if her current tx does not produce the desired results. I hope this helped! love, g

Posts.Content: nosurrender wrote: I couldn't find her thread, so I am starting this one... I have an update on wonderful Deb. She is off the bad chemo and on a great new one that has shown amazing results with TNBC. She had a bit of a rough start with it, mostly because they didn't premedicate her because they didn't know how she would react- and as we know- they don't give us the pre-meds until they know what to premedicate.  But she is feeling better every day.  She will hopefully get that port out and have her chemo given through a lumbar puncture since she only needs to be infused every two weeks. This will give Deb her life back, because that port has caused her so many problems. She still needs our prayers and good thoughts- but John said the best three words to me I could hear..... "She's Still Deb!" Love, g nosurrenderbreastcancerhelp.org ~What a long, strange trip it's been... Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Deb C Update nosurrender LuAnnH

Posts.Content: nosurrender wrote: Hi, This is a great thread. If someone is looking at surgery I just wanted you to know that almost six years ago I had a lumpectomy with full axillary dissection for a trip negative cancer. It was followed by chemo and rads. Another, brand new estrogen positive cancer was found this February and I had a bilateral mastectomy with tissue expanders. I am currently in chemo but when I am done I will need rads and then I hope to have my final touch surgery done with silicone implants. I would be glad to help anyone new. Getting a diagnosis is bad enough, then you think the surgery is worse than the diagnosis, but after your done with surgery it will seem easy when you compare it to starting chemo. This beast makes us tough cookies who are true warriors. Getting cancer removed from your body is empowering. And if you check out the recon thread you will see that many are happy with their results. I know I am. Good luck to all, g nosurrenderbreastcancerhelp.org ~What a long, strange trip it's been... Posts.Content: May 9, 2008 06:27PM nosurrender wrote: Hey April Girls, I had dose dense, sequential chemo that I started in April in 2007. I had Adriamycin, abraxane and Xeloda. I finished in December and I just wanted to check in with you newbies and tell you I am fine now. I have no lingering side effects. My hair is about 4 inches long. And I am no worse for the wear, as my mother would say. Make sure you drink a lot of liquids the first two days after your infusion Take all your meds on schedule- even if you feel fine- because you can prevent nausea but it is hard to stop it once it starts Never let your stomach get too empty, always have something to nibble on Keep active- it really does help And if you feel tired, lie down and rest! Don't push yourselves. I wore a wig- I bought it before my hair came out. I had it styled to my style and my color so when the time came I looked just like myself. I didn't always wear it. When I worked in the garden I would wear a hat with an attached pony tail and of course I had lots of scarves. If your head gets hot and itchy from the wig try some Sea Breeze on your scalp. It really is soothing. Remember, this is not forever and you will be done with it. Good luck!!! hugs, g

But then she had another set back and the travel would have been too much for her. My dad really liked her, too. Remember when she was first dx'd and she was determined to continue with her master's degree? She signed up and then got dx'd stage IV.  She was so giving, so caring and her faith helped sustain all of us... Love and hugs to all of you, g

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2007 07:21PM - edited Oct 2, 2007 07:21PM by nosurrender Hi, I am sorry you are going through all this. One oncologist told me that you have 18 weeks from surgery to start chemo as the maximum time. I think that is pushing it in my opinion. My current oncologist said I should start as soon as I was healed from my surgery.  You do have some wiggle room so don't worry if you don't start immediately, but don't go past the 18 week mark. I wish you luck. You will get through this. It seems really hard and confusing now, but soon things will fall into place.

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2008 07:24PM - edited Oct 6, 2008 07:25PM by nosurrender This is very upsetting, I know. I had to get a chest MRI and my onc scheduled it and I walked into the radiation place and they had me fill out the form if I had any "foreign objects" in my body. I remember saying something like, except for the expanders, and the tech said that was OK. Then it dawned on me at the last minute that I had metal in my expander ports because they use that magnet before the fills. So I called my PS from the radiation place and spoke to his nurse and they told me not to have it done. I honestly don't think the tech knew the difference between an expander and an implant. Later, when I saw my PS, he told me the MRI can make the expander port move or become inaccessible.  I have had a ruptured expander and it doesn't hurt and it doesn't cause any damage because it is only filled with saline. But your expanders may be still be OK. You will probably have to get a sonogram to see where everything is now. But it sounds like they stopped the test before it was too late. It all sucks - I know- esp when you are in the middle of all of it. I had rads with my expanders too- and that was all OK too, so I hope that eases your mind some. Hugs g
Posts.Title: Shouldn't of had MRI w/ EXPANDER! LUVmy2girlZ Looneymom

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2008 07:58PM nosurrender wrote: I haven't been online in a couple of days, I had no idea that Kari had taken this turn... now to read that she has passed is just so heartbreaking and shocking. I have always felt like she was the embodiment of support and love and caring here at BCO. She always had encouragment for all of us whenever we felt down. She always showed us such optimism even in the face of her own, very serious, battle that she was waging. She was always here and now the  "always" of knowing she was here is now gone from us.  My heartfelt prayers go out to her husband and children and extended family. I also want to reach out to those of you who were so close to her here on the boards. Donna, I know how hard this must have been for you to write.  Victoria and Fumi, I am so sorry. It is getting harder and harder to lose sisters. Why can't they find something to stop this? Another beautiful young mother is gone. You would think that after all this time we would have words of wisdom, but the more we lose the words seem to go with them. May God bless dear Kari. Rest well, kind soul. gina

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2009 06:32PM nosurrender wrote: Hey newly diagnosed triple negs- I was diagnosed with Triple Neg in 2001 and I am ok and my sister just had her 4 year cancerversary from her diagnosis of TN. I just met a woman who was diagnosed in 1998 with positive nodes, highly aggressive TN and she is completely fine today. This is the hardest time, right now. But once you get your plan in place and you are actively fighting you feel better, more in control. And then, one day you see you are all done with treatments and surgeries and your life is waiting for you. Big hugs, g
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed w/aggressive IDC theredheadamy kim40

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2008 09:35AM nosurrender wrote: I did Xeloda last year.  I was warned to watch out for bad diarrhea and hand and foot syndrome. If you stop the minute it gets bad, the better it is for your doc to manage it. I did fine for the first 11 days and then the diarhea hit. I called my onc and he reduced my dosage. We had to tinker with how many pills I took a day depending on the s/e's, but for the most part, it was not a bad tx for me. In the morning I would drink a shot of liquid Immodium and I put Bag Balm on my feet and hands and was careful around hot water. I found that Dr. Scholls Foot cream was also soothing when the skin on my feet got bad. Once your doc finds a dosage that you can tolerate, it is much easier. Good luck with it.... big hugs to you. g

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2008 11:07PM nosurrender wrote: Dear Kari, I am crying along with all the others here who love you so. You have been such an amazingly positive presence here and are someone I look up to always. I hope that you have what happened to one of my close friends happen to you. She was taken off chemo because it became too toxic for her liver and was referred to hospice care. Once she was off the chemo, her liver improved and she had a wonderful quality of life for a long time. Longer than anyone could have imagined. And she spent that time with her baby daughter and husband and felt like her old self again for the first time in a long time. I pray that your liver will respond as well and that you really feel like your old self while enjoying your vacation. My prayers are with you  - I hope you can feel all the love coming to you now from all your sisters here who are all holding you close in their hearts. Love, Gina

Posts.Content: Oct 26, 2007 10:22PM nosurrender wrote: I had a bilateral mast with tissue expanders in march. Since I am allergic to narcotics I had to do the whole thing on Tylenol! But you might want to ask about a muscle relaxer. Skelaxin is a good one because it is non narcotic and doesn't make you loopy but works really well. Your PS can give you an RX for it. It sounds like you are having muscle spasms and that is more painful than anything!! Good luck- it DOES get better!!! g my website
